Re-imagining frozen yogurt

  • By Amanda Ruehlen, Danielle Tepper, and Reyna Desai
  • Multimedia Journalists
Dec. 03 1:00 am
  • one comment
  • E-mail
  • Print

Do you like this story?

Click here to see what students had to say about doing everything on the iPhone 4

Sources

  • Seungmok Kim, Orange Leaf Owner
  • June Kim, Orange Leaf Manager
  • Jonathan Midei, Orange Leaf Employee
  • Kana Kuroda, UNC-Chapel Hill Student
  • Mark Sperry, TCBY Owner
  • Claire Weintraub, customer, Chapel Hill resident

CHAPEL HILL
Imagine combining peanut butter, pineapple and chocolate syrup for a frozen yogurt treat.

While Orange Leaf employee Jonathan Midei said he would never eat that combination, the store is overflowing with customers.

Seungmok Kim, Orange Leaf’s owner, said his store’s “self-serve” approach to frozen yogurt provides customers with a unique experience.

Kim came to Chapel Hill from South Korea in 2003, and this year, he discovered a way to bring his own flavor to town.

His branch of the frozen yogurt franchise Orange Leaf opened in April at the Timberlyne Shopping Center off Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard.

“We put delicious, healthy and fun [together], so this is a totally new concept of this kind of business,” Kim said. “People go crazy with that.”

Kim said that the local universities and the working population attracted him to open the store in the area.

“Here, around three to four miles within this distance, we don’t have any kind of frozen dessert items,” he said. “Also, there is so much young people, like [from] UNC-Chapel Hill and Duke, and also professionals . . . which is why we chose this location.”

The owner also said his yogurt sells at a reasonable price — 39 cents per ounce — considering its high quality. He said the cost of shipping the flavors from Italy added to the price.

“Some of the stores charge like 42, 45, 47, 49 [cents per ounce], but we choose this [price]. Best quality, most comparative price . . .  and best service; that is our idea,” he said.

Most yogurt purchases end up costing between $5 to $7, Midei said.

Orange Leaf, in its mission to give customers full control over their desserts, provides a variety of flavors and toppings.

“Everyone is happy. We now currently have 14 flavors selling,” Kim said.

He added that many toppings come from fresh fruit.

“We just buy [fresh fruits] every day. We do not go only one place. Costco, Sam’s Club and several other markets. Every day we check and get the best ones and most fresh ones.”

While Orange Leaf considers itself unique in its customer-centered concepts, it is not the only frozen yogurt store in Chapel Hill.

The Yogurt Pump, located at 106 W. Franklin St., attracts students from the UNC-CH campus. Another local store, TCBY, sells frozen yogurt as well as other dessert specialties from its location at the Eastgate Shopping Center off of East Franklin Street.

The Yogurt Pump differs from Orange Leaf in its selection of flavors.

“I’m more of a fruit flavor person, and [Orange Leaf] has a lot more fruit,” said Kana Kuroda, a junior at UNC.”[The Yogurt Pump] has a lot of like chocolate and vanilla, and I don’t like that as much as tart flavors.”

TCBY serves 24 flavors every day. Owner Mark Sperry has visited Orange Leaf and found both positive and negative aspects of the store.

“I enjoyed the concept, enjoyed the atmosphere,” Sperry said. “I wasn’t thrilled about the product in general.”

Sperry said that TCBY’s product is healthier than the frozen yogurt sold at Orange Leaf, although he added that this might not make a difference to customers. He also said that, while Orange Leaf markets its product as “all natural,” it is difficult to regulate what that term really means.

In spite of the competition, store manager June Kim — the owner’s son — remains confident in Orange Leaf’s ability to attract customers.

“We actually try to attract students but also families, especially the young kids because they like sweets,” he said.

The store has appealed to students and local residents alike. Among Orange Leaf’s frequent customers is 14-year-old Claire Weintraub.

“This is my favorite yogurt place around here,” she said. “They have a lot of cool flavors, and I like that you can do it yourself.”

Seungmok Kim has plans to expand the store to two more locations in the state.

“Originally, we tried to open three stores, one here in Chapel Hill, and the other one in Raleigh and the third one in Cary,” he said.

Quick cooperation from the landlord in Chapel Hill led to the 1129 Weaver Dairy Rd. location at the Timberlyne Shopping Center opening before the others, Seungmok Kim said.

The second location at Crossroads Plaza in Cary should open in February, he said.

“We opened April 2 of this year. . . . This is wonderful. This is much more than what we expected,” Kim said in reference to the store’s success.

Midei said the store stays busy.

“I see too many customers a day, I couldn’t even give you an estimate,” he said.

This story was reported as part of the J463 Digital Newsdesk Production class.
